hints.content: Start by understanding what an arithmetic progression (AP) is. An array is in AP if the difference between consecutive elements is constant. For example, in the array [1, 3, 5], the difference is 2.
Consider how you might check if the elements of the array can be rearranged to form an AP. What properties must the minimum and maximum values of the array have?
Think about sorting the array first. Why might sorting help you determine if the array can form an AP? What will the differences between consecutive elements look like after sorting?
Once you have a sorted array, calculate the common difference using the first two elements. This will be your reference difference for the rest of the elements.
After calculating the common difference, iterate through the sorted array and check if the difference between each pair of consecutive elements matches the common difference you calculated.
Remember to handle edge cases. What if the array has duplicate elements? Will it affect the ability to form an AP?
Consider the constraints given in the problem. How do the constraints on the array length and the range of values affect your approach?
Think about the time complexity of your solution. Sorting the array takes O(n log n) time. Is this acceptable given the constraints?
If you find that any pair of consecutive elements does not have the same difference, you can immediately return false. What would be the return value if all checks pass?
Finally, remember to return the correct type as specified in the problem statement. If the array can be rearranged to form an AP, return true; otherwise, return false.

questionNotes: The array can contain duplicate elements.
Return type must be boolean (true or false).
